entry.title: Apple‚Äôs Bold Design Choice of Making Things Look Bad

link.title: Apple‚Äôs Bold Design Choice of Making Things Look Bad

entry.content:
Introduction

Apple enjoys a unique position in the mobile business. It manages a platform that runs in an exclusive range of devices. For developers, this means that they can expect their app to run reasonably similar to how it runs on their own devices.

This affords Apple to make design choices that make ‚Äúthings look bad‚Äù. And reasonably expect developers to make the necessary changes to make their app look good on Apple devices

Case 1: The Notch

The notch is effectively a visual modification to the already existing status bar. And the status bar is part of the system interface, not the app interface.

Android‚Äôs solution to optimising the app interfaces to the notched displays was exactly this. They treated the notch area as the status bar. The app didn‚Äôt have to be bothered by it. It continued to work as before

iOS, on the other hand, added huge black areas on the top and bottom for apps that didn‚Äôt claim to be optimized. Effectively reducing the app interfaces real estate to 4.7‚Äù on a 5.8‚Äù screen.

In hindsight, this paid off. Nearly all iOS apps started working well on screens with display cutouts very soon

Case 2: Tinted Icons

This is again something both iOS and Android did. But Android is far more lenient with its approach, using the default icon as a fallback icon if tinted icon doesn‚Äôt exist in the manifest

iOS again doesn‚Äôt use a fallback, instead choosing to make the icon look potentially bad by applying a tint over it.

This attracted a lot of initial criticism but is very much in line with how Apple does things. The onus falls on the app developers to make their app fit into this system

entry.title: Book Notes: Norwegian Wood (by Haruki Murakami)

link.title: Book Notes: Norwegian Wood (by Haruki Murakami)

entry.content:
‚õ∞ What It‚Äôs About

A coming-of-age story set in 1960s Japan, narrated by Toru Watanabe, a college student who reflects on his past, particularly his relationships with two women: Naoko and Midori. The novel explores themes of love, loss, memory, and mental health, set against the backdrop of political unrest and youth culture in postwar Japan.

üîç How I Discovered It

Multiple sources recommended the book to me. My friend Mazin had recommended it back in 2020. A girlfriend had recommended it again in 2021. Finally decided to give up my reservations and try this in 2024

üß† Thoughts

Loved it. The book has a matter-of-fact voice like that of a scientific journal. Murakami intends to re-kindle the pain or experience of the primary themes of the book of love, loss, memory and mental health instead of bringing a brand new experience to readers. That makes this book personal for its readers

What I Liked About It

I liked the writing style of Murakami. It‚Äôs vert matter-of-factly. Doesn‚Äôt use intensifiers in his writing. Bringing such technical writing to matters of love, death and sex is interesting. Authors are usually careful approaching the subject of sex in their books. Murakami‚Äôs treatment of sex as if in a scientific journal is unique. A kiss is two lips caressing each other. An orgasm is the process of getting rid of cum. The bold explorations of loss and love is what makes this book universally loved.

What I Didn‚Äôt Like About It

There‚Äôs some general hate in the wild west of Internet about Murakami‚Äôs treatment of women.

ü•∞ Who Would Like It?

Anyone who has experienced intense feelings of love, loss, memory and mental health!

üìö Related Books

  • My first of this kind

entry.title: Off by 100% Bias
entry.content:
Today I learnt about Off by 100% bias.

When a consumer sees ‚Äú130% more‚Äù, they likely do not put much thought or effort into actually computing what it means,‚Äù she adds. Instead, the consumer‚Äôs mind ‚Äújumps‚Äù to the first thing that makes sense, the straight ‚Äú30% more‚Äù calculation.

const number = 50;
const delta = 25;

const final = number + delta; // 75;

const percentage_increase = delta / number; // 25 / 50 = 0.5; i.e 50%;
const x_times = final / number; // 75/50 = 1.5; i.e, 1.5x

This is even more evident in increases of more than 100%;

const number = 50;
const increase = 75;

const final_number = number + delta; // 125;

const percentage_increase = delta / number; // 75 / 50 = 1.5; i.e 150%
const x_times = final / number; // 125 / 50 = 2.5; i.e 2.5x

The true reason is that the factors in percentage are the previous number and the delta. Whereas, when you calculate x times value, you factor the final number and the previous number.

The final number and the previous number will have a higher difference. Therefore, showing x times value will appear to have a higher magnitude.

Sources

https://coxtoday.smu.edu/2022/02/28/consumer-marketing-math-even-the-numerate-are-off-by-100/

entry.title: Recursion in React
entry.content:
TLDR;

TIL that you can have recursive components in React!

üí° React uses one-way data flow, passing data down the component hierarchy from parent to child component


So while thinking in React, it may not immediately occur that you can call a parent inside the child! But it is possible

Consider a Data Structure like this:

const comments = [
  {
    content: "Comment 1",
    level: 0,
    comments: [
      {
        content: "Comment 1 > 1",
        level: 1,
        comments: [
          {
            content: "Comment 1 > 1 > 1",
            level: 2,
            comments: [],
          },
        ],
      },
      {
        content: "Comment 1 > 2",
        level: 1,
        comments: [],
      },
    ],
  },
  {
    content: "Comment 2",
    level: 0,
    comments: [],
  },
];

Doing this in Javascript

function displayComments(comments) {
  return comments.reduce((acc, comment) => {
    const prefix = Array(comment.level)
      .fill("|")
      .reduce((acc, item) => `${acc} ${item}`, "");

    const moreComments = displayComments(comment.comments);

    const stringToReturn = `${prefix} ${comment.content} \n ${moreComments}`;
    return `${acc} ${stringToReturn}`;
  }, "");
}

Result:

Doing this in React

function Comment({ comment }) {
  const prefix = Array(comment.level)
    .fill("|")
    .reduce((acc, item) => `${acc} ${item}`, "");
  return (
    <div>
      {prefix} {comment.content}
      <Comments comments={comment.comments} />
    </div>
  );
}

export default function Comments({ comments }) {
  return comments.map((comment) => {
    return <Comment comment={comment} />;
  });
}

Result:

Actual example of rendering a comment tree

It‚Äôs unlikely we‚Äôll be using | prefixes when actually building a comment tree. We‚Äôll more likely be playing around with padding and margin.

Here‚Äôs a code example of actual comment tree rendering in React with TailwindCSS: https://github.com/rahulakrishna/hackrmn/blob/master/src/app/[storylist]/comments/[commentid]/comment-block.js

References

  • Thinking in React: https://react.dev/learn/thinking-in-react
  • hackrmn repo: https://github.com/rahulakrishna/hackrmn/tree/master

entry.title: Arc Search
entry.content:
What is it?

Here is what Arc Search has to say about Arc Search!

Basic Stuff it does

It does the basic stuff you expect a web browser to do. You can use it to open and browse websites and search the web.

Cool Stuff it does!

The cool stuff is the Browse for me feature.

This is very much like Google‚Äôs ‚Äúfeatured snippets‚Äù but collates information from various sources

Here Google shows the answer and source

Whereas Arc:

This is data from multiple sources. Now one useful thing you can do with Google is where you add the keyword ‚Äúreddit‚Äù to the search query to find a thread that may contain deeper discussion or specific answer. So you can ask Arc Search:

I‚Äôve found asking what Reddit, Twitter or Hacker News thinks about specific topics and gotten interesting results. Just the contrast in what the user bases talk about is interesting.

Consider yourself in a bookstore. Using Arc to search ‚Äúwhat does reddit think about Radical Candor‚Äù is much simpler and faster than searching Google ‚ÄúRadical Candor reddit‚Äù.

Drawbacks

  • It does display the sources for your data. But it‚Äôs AI and AI gets it wrong at times.
All the text in this page is right about me. But the person shown in the picture is not me. That‚Äôs another person who has the same name as me
All other data on the page is impressive.
  • Less prominence to sources. Look at the sunscreen related screenshots in this page. It shows you where it sources the data from. In a tiny text below the blocks. There‚Äôs also a list of links if you‚Äôre interested in learning more. But the UI is trying to hint that there‚Äôs enough data here that you don‚Äôt need to click through those links. I‚Äôm not sure how you can solve this problem or even if this is a problem. They probably don‚Äôt want to replace Google Search. Where you are presented with titles and content hidden behind links. Ben Werdmuller wrote about this problem at: https://werd.io/2024/stripping-the-web-of-its-humanity

References

  • Ben Werdmuller at: https://werd.io/2024/stripping-the-web-of-its-humanity
  • Arc Blog on Arc Search: https://arc.net/blog/arc-search

entry.title: Arc Browser
entry.content:
Web Browser

A Web Browser, ultimately, is an application that lets you send a request to a URL and displays the HTML response on your screen. Apart from displaying simple markup, it also has the ability to run JavaScript and style using CSS.

Web Page

Web Pages have been relying on the ‚Äúrunning JavaScript‚Äù part more and more. When Angular 1 came out, you were supposed to run the JS bundle inside your HTML. But most frameworks now expect you to render the markup inside JS. Even static websites now have a largely JS based codebase.

We‚Äôre seeing more and more ‚Äúweb-apps‚Äù instead of ‚Äúweb-sites‚Äù. This change makes a browser more akin to an Operating System running apps. Instead of the original concept of an application that renders markup.

In other words, we‚Äôre ‚Äúdoing more things‚Äù with our browsers than ‚Äúreading things‚Äù with them. Arc Browser tries to bring some of those OS type UX into the browser world.

Launcher

Every Operating Systems have some kind of ‚ÄúLauncher‚Äù.

Probably the biggest upgrade in Browser terms is when Google made the URL bar of Chrome work more like a ‚ÄúLauncher‚Äù. You weren‚Äôt any more expected to precisely type in the URL of the page you had to go to. Google would actually prefer it if you first went to google.com and clicked on a link from there.

Arc changes this by opening a Spotlight-like Command Palette every time you hit Cmd+T.

This lets you do much more than just start a search or open a URL. For instance:

This may seem like a radical change, but the fact is many applications have already mapped Cmd+T to such an action.

VS Code shows this:

Slack shows this:

Tab Management

Window Management in Operating Systems and Tab Management in Browsers have a lot in common. But all major browsers still rely on the same Ctrl-Tab shortcut to switch to the next tab. Arc changes this.

Space Management

Spaces is another cool general OS feature that Browsers have tried to implement, but it hasn‚Äôt fared well.

Spaces on macOS

Safari‚Äôs Space Management is called Tab Groupings. And while this gets synced across devices and is pretty useful if you‚Äôre into organising things, it‚Äôs almost always hidden away from view. No keyboard shortcuts exist. It‚Äôs almost like a way to stash away a group of tabs rather than an intuitive way to organise tabs.

Chrome has an even simpler Tab Grouping that essentially lets you put a label next to tabs.

Arc simply lets you have this small icons at the bottom of your tabs list. Where you can do a Horizontal scroll to switch between tabs. Also you can find tabs open in other tab groups from the ‚ÄúSpotlight-like‚Äù search thingie.

Vertical Tabs

Horizontal Tabs are hard to work with if you have a lot of tabs open.

Vertical Tabs offer a better view of the page title. It‚Äôs also essential for the scroll to switch space feature

Renaming Tabs

Arc lets you rename tabs. Ridiculously simple. But really useful!

Theming

AI Features and Split View

Arc clearly has an idea of how you browse the web and actively tries to enhance it. One day into trying out Arc, it completely changed how I use HN

Hover over links to get a summary. Open in split view so I never lose context of the HN link that took me there.

entry.title: Visual History of World Cup Logos

link.title: Visual History of World Cup Logos

entry.content:
Introduction

World Cup logos are a visual representation of the time, culture and the general vibe of the host nation and the time period in which it is held. There are three major world cups that happen. In order of popularity, they are:

  1. FIFA World Cup
  2. ICC Cricket World Cup
  3. Rugby World Cup

Nearly all world cup logos look reasonably bad or illegible in dark mode. So this page is better read in light mode

The Actual Cups

Logos before 2014

FIFA World Cup started in 1930. It did not have a logo for a long time, rather a poster existed. Cricket World Cup debuted in 1975 and the Rugby World Cup in 1987.

Poster Era (1930-1966)

Logo Era

This is probably what can be considered the first logo

The last of Freeform logos

FIFA seems to have set on the logo format back in 2014. But it definitely took a better shape in 2018 and 2022. ICC had nothing resembling the cup, while the Rugby World Cup had no specific World Cup Logo before 2019.

The first logos to strictly follow the format

Latest Logos

The latest FIFA World Cup happened in 2022, ICC Cricket World Cup and the Rugby World Cup in 2023. The hosts were Qatar, India and France respectively.

Seems to be the case that all major World Cups are going for a format onto which host nations can apply their visual pattern. This behaviour is relatively new and started with these World Cups during the 2018-19 time period. Looking at the previous logos

Putting these together

Rugby has a similar visual identity that still allows for freedom across their various world cups. With 6 logos following the visual pattern, they‚Äôre clearly ahead

Rugby

Cricket

Football

Bonus: T20 Cricket World Cup

The T20 World Cup logos from 2007 to 2012 saw host nations having to write the word T20 in their choice of design

This changed in 2014 and ICC decided on a more restrictive format where you could only change the colours

entry.title: Loading vs Fetching
entry.content:
The Basics

  • No Data + Fetching Data = LOADING
  • Yes Data + Fetching Data = FETCHING

Why?

As long as the data we have is not invalid. We have no reason to hide it away from the user.

Examples from around the world

Loading Fetching
YouTube Loading State YouTube Fetching State
Apollo App Loading State Apollo App Fetching State
Fotmob Loading State Fotmob Fetching State

Important Exception

We must be careful not to trigger the fetching state when the data is invalid

entry.title: Illusion of Touch
entry.content:
TIL

It‚Äôs physically impossible to touch anything because we‚Äôre made up of atoms. When we get too close to an object, our electrons and the electrons of that object will repel each other. However, our brain interprets the sensation of those repulsion forces as the illusion of ‚Äútouch‚Äù even though they never actually touch.

entry.title: Budgeting Tool with Numbers + Shortcuts
entry.content:
The Case for Default Applications

Simple default applications often surpass complex specialized solutions due to their ease of use, efficiency, and reliability. They offer a user-friendly experience, are optimized for common use cases, and prioritize simplicity and functionality, making them more efficient and effective for everyday tasks.

Prerequisite


  • An Apple Device - (iPhone, Mac or iPad)

  • Numbers - Default App - (iOS, iPadOS. macOS)

  • Shortcuts - Default App - (iOS, iPadOS)

What do we expect from Budget?

The proposed budgeting tool will incorporate two distinct sheets: a ‚ÄòBudget‚Äô sheet for resource allocation and a ‚ÄòTransactions‚Äô sheet for recording financial transactions. The ‚ÄòBudget‚Äô sheet is intended to be established at the commencement of each month, with subsequent modifications primarily occurring within the ‚ÄòTransactions‚Äô sheet. It is anticipated that updates to the ‚ÄòTransactions‚Äô sheet will automatically reflect in the ‚ÄòBudget‚Äô sheet, ensuring real-time accuracy of the budgeting data.

Doing this in Numbers

Fortunately, all these functionalities are incorporated within a pre-constructed default template in Numbers, providing a seamless user experience.

Let‚Äôs proceed to validate the functionality of this process:

On to the Shortcut
